para.paratext: O.C.G.A. § 24-9-902 tracks Fed. R. Evid. 902 regarding self-authenticating documents. Under these provisions, extrinsic evidence of authenticity as a condition precedent to admissibility is not required with respect to (1) domestic public documents under seal,[1] (2) domestic public documents not under seal that are signed and certified in the official capacity of an officer or employee of a public entity, (3) foreign public documents, (4) certified copies of public records,[2] (5) official publications, (6) newspapers and periodicals,[3] (7) trade inscriptions, signs, tags, or labels purporting to have been affixed in the course of business and indicating ownership, control, or origin, (8) acknowledged documents, (9) commercial paper and related documents,[4] (10) any signature, document, or other matter declared by act of Congress to be presumptively or prima facie genuine or authentic, (11) certified domestic records of regularly conducted activity, and (12) certified foreign records of regularly conducted activity. Such documents are “self-authenticating” in that testimony or other extrinsic evidence of authenticity is not required.
The testimony of an expert that is based on evidence that would otherwise not meet the admissibility requirements under O.C.G.A. § 24-9-902 for purposes of summary judgment is admissible at trial.[5]

Under O.C.G.A. § 24-9-902(11), an adverse party must be given written notice and an opportunity to inspect prior to trial. Where it was evident from a motion for summary judgment that the moving party intended to rely on self-authenticating documents, and the respondent did not object to those documents, the requisite notice was provided.[6] However, said records may be admitted even though the certification accompanying the records is not notarized or under penalty of perjury.[7] The Court of Appeals has differentiated between a police report (which is inadmissible), and an intoxylizer log, which was not.[8]

Under O.C.G.A. § 40-14-17, the state may introduce a self-authenticating list of models of laser devices approved by the Department of Public Safety to test speed. However, the state may rely on other evidence to authenticate the device.[9]

Residual hearsay exception contained in federal evidence rule did not allow for introduction into evidence of report from Georgia Bureau of Investigation (GBI) regarding tests performed on female alleged rape victim suing university for damages, when report was inadmissible due to failure to authenticate through placement of original state seal. Ross v. Corporation of Mercer University, 506 F. Supp. 2d 1325, 225 Ed. Law Rep. 334 (M.D. Ga. 2007).

Court documents which had not been certified by the custodian of records or otherwise authenticated were not admissible for purposes of summary judgment motions. Sherman v. Sunsong America, Inc., 485 F. Supp. 2d 1070 (D. Neb. 2007).
Printed materials purporting to be periodicals are self-authenticating. Sherman v. Sunsong America, Inc., 485 F. Supp. 2d 1070 (D. Neb. 2007).
A guaranty is a self-authenticating document. Jaycee Atlanta Development, LLC v. Providence Bank, 330 Ga. App. 322, 765 S.E.2d 536 (2014).
Fields v. Taylor, 340 Ga. App. 706, 797 S.E.2d 127 (2017).
Salas v. JP Morgan Chase Bank, N.A., 334 Ga. App. 274, 779 S.E.2d 48 (2015).
Jones v. State, 345 Ga. App. 14, 812 S.E.2d 337 (2018).
Lafavor v. State, 334 Ga. App. 125, 778 S.E.2d 377 (2015).
